stem: The emergency management nurse is reviewing response protocols for suspected terrorism agents. Based on the documentation in the Decontamination Protocol Checklist, match each agent to the correct nursing priority.

tabs.title: Incident Overview
tabs.content:
09:00: Intelligence reports a credible threat of an aerosolized release at a public transit hub. 
09:30: Multiple patients arrive at the ED with 'flu-like' symptoms and dark, necrotic skin lesions. 
10:00: Another group of patients arrives with pinpoint pupils, SLUDGE symptoms, and respiratory distress.

tabs.title: Decontamination Protocol Checklist
tabs.content:

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content:
Patient Cluster 1 (Nerve): Bradycardia, RR 8, Copious secretions.

rationale.correct: Anthrax (r1) is treated with Ciprofloxacin and is not contagious person-to-person (c1). Nerve agents (r2) require immediate decontamination and Atropine to reverse the cholinergic crisis (c2). Smallpox (r3) is highly contagious and requires stringent isolation (c3). Botulism (r4) causes descending paralysis, requiring early ventilatory support (c4).
clinicalPearls: Anthrax skin lesions are classic: Painless black eschars (Sores).
SLUDGE: Salivation, Lacrimation, Urination, Defecation, GI distress, Emesis (Nerve agent cues).
Smallpox rash: All lesions are at the SAME stage of development (unlike chickenpox).

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that Anthrax is NOT transmitted person-to-person. Standard precautions are sufficient.
